data.text: Small Bikepacking Pan for Cooking and Eating Out Of

I am new to backpacking/ bikepacking. Can anyone suggest a small pan for cooking and eating out of. Is Aluminium, stainless or titanium the best? Also I need some light utensils ie a fork and spoon. Looking for light weight .Thanks.

Things like this are quite small and simple. You can also fit the small gas bottle inside the set along with the jet boil piece. Shayson Camping Stove + Pan, Portable Outdoor Backpacking Cookware Hiking Cooking Stove Butane Propane Burner for Gas Canister With Piezo Ignition https://amzn.eu/d/2JmTrZ1
data.author: Mark Vernon

data.text: Stainless is heavy, ti can be lighter becuase it's a stronger than aluminium but I think being even thinner makes it more prone to burning. Used a Chinese Windsea heat transfer pan, cheap Chinese stove and a 250g (I think) canister which both fit inside the pan set
data.author: Henk Kommers

data.text: Aluminium is good, as is titanium. Titanium less durable and more prone to burning. Steel is heavier but more durable and can be used on wood fire if you have issues with gas.
data.author: Ray D. Chaplin

data.text: Plain aluminium (rather than coated) cooks well but some have issues with aluminium and potential links to dementia. Coated pans are also looked upon with disfavour. If you were using these over long periods you might take more notice of this. Stainless is heavy, food doesn't burn so easily. Titanium is light but expensive. The issue some have is that food burns a little easier. Jetboil are really fast at boiling water. They really are best for doing just that, so best used with dehydrated foods you just add water to. Their design, pot mounted on top of canister, can be a little unstable. Some people use gas stoves with short flexible hoses so the pans are more stable. The OEX vulcan is good for this at the cheap end of the market. Piezo works, but always carry a second ignition source because piezo doesn't always work. Cutlery? A long-handled spork. The thing is.... are you actually going to cook? Some long term walkers and cyclists only make coffee in the morning and a drink at night. They pick up food on the way, they eat fruit and bread with spread combinations. In other words, think about needs first, then buy, practice on short trips and be prepared to change the whole lot.
data.author: Peter Jeynes

data.text: Most things can be cooked in a 750 pot/cup however, if you want something a bit larger then look at the Alpkit Alipot set. Plastic utensils are good but can burn, Ali/Ti are light but scratch. GoOutdoors have a nice folding set.

data.text: I’ve recently upgraded from stainless to ti it’s used far less fuel! I can recommend the Alpkit ones, I’ve a bowl and a cup, I cook on hexi block/wood so heat output is less than gas so burning not an issue.

data.text: Alpkit 750 or 900 pots cover most eventualities and you can fit a small gas cannister and compact stove in them. They also come in wee mesh bags whicknare surprisingly handy at camp for putting all yer wee things in
